Regular use of inhaled corticosteroids or other anti-inflammatory drugs to control inflammation and prevent asthma attacks.
Identifying and avoiding triggers such as pollen, dust mites, pet dander, or certain foods. Using air purifiers or allergy shots may also be beneficial.
Quitting smoking, avoiding exposure to secondhand smoke, maintaining a healthy weight, and regular exercise can help manage asthma symptoms.
Working with a healthcare provider to develop a personalized action plan outlining steps to take in case of an asthma attack or worsening symptoms.
Use of insulin injections, oral medications (such as metformin), or other drugs to help regulate blood sugar levels.
Following a balanced diet that includes monitoring carbohydrate intake, eating at regular intervals, and avoiding sugary or high-glycemic foods.
Engaging in physical activity such as walking, jogging, swimming, or cycling to help improve insulin sensitivity and control blood sugar levels.
Regularly checking blood glucose levels using a glucometer or continuous glucose monitoring system to track fluctuations and adjust treatment as needed.
Maintaining a healthy weight, quitting smoking, limiting alcohol consumption, managing stress, and getting adequate sleep to help manage diabetes effectively.
Prescription of antihypertensive drugs such as ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics, calcium channel blockers, or other medications to lower blood pressure.
Adopting a heart-healthy diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and low-fat dairy while limiting sodium, saturated fats, and processed foods.
Engaging in aerobic activities like walking, jogging, cycling, or swimming for at least 30 minutes most days of the week to improve cardiovascular health and lower BP.
Losing excess weight through a combination of diet and exercise, as even a modest weight loss can significantly reduce blood pressure in overweight or obese individuals.
Practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, yoga, or mindfulness to help alleviate stress and promote overall cardiovascular health.
Taking iron supplements, either in pill form or intravenously, to replenish low iron levels in the body and support the production of hemoglobin.
Consuming iron-rich foods such as red meat, poultry, fish, beans, lentils, tofu, spinach, fortified cereals, and dried fruits to boost iron intake naturally.
Taking supplements containing vitamin B12, folic acid, or vitamin C, which are essential for red blood cell production and iron absorption.
Addressing underlying conditions that may be causing or contributing to anemia, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, chronic diseases, or autoimmune disorders.
Receiving a blood transfusion in severe cases of anemia, particularly when hemoglobin levels are critically low and immediate intervention is necessary.
Surgical removal of cancerous tumors or affected tissue, often used as the primary treatment for localized cancers or as part of a multimodal approach for advanced cases.
Administration of cytotoxic drugs to kill cancer cells or prevent their growth and spread, typically used in combination with surgery, radiation, or targeted therapy.
Delivery of high-energy radiation to target and destroy cancer cells, often used alone or in combination with surgery or chemotherapy to treat various types of cancer.
Treatment that enhances the body's immune response to recognize and destroy cancer cells, utilizing medications such as checkpoint inhibitors or CAR T-cell therapy.

Prescription antiviral drugs such as oseltamivir (Tamiflu), zanamivir (Relenza), or peramivir (Rapivab) may be recommended to reduce the severity and duration of influenza symptoms.
Getting plenty of rest and staying hydrated by drinking fluids such as water, broth, herbal tea, or electrolyte solutions to help the body fight off the infection and recover.
Using over-the-counter medications such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen to alleviate fever, body aches, and other flu symptoms, following package instructions for dosage and usage.
Breathing in steam from a warm shower or using a humidifier to ease congestion, soothe sore throat, and relieve nasal symptoms associated with influenza infection.
Practicing good hygiene such as frequent handwashing, avoiding close contact with sick individuals, and getting an annual flu vaccine to prevent influenza infection altogether.
Over-the-counter or prescription medications such as loratadine (Claritin), cetirizine (Zyrtec), or diphenhydramine (Benadryl) to block the action of histamine and alleviate allergy symptoms.
Prescription nasal sprays like fluticasone (Flonase) or budesonide (Rhinocort) to reduce inflammation and congestion in the nasal passages, providing relief from allergic rhinitis.
Oral or nasal decongestants such as pseudoephedrine (Sudafed) or oxymetazoline (Afrin) to relieve nasal congestion and sinus pressure caused by allergic reactions.
Allergy shots (subcutaneous immunotherapy) or sublingual tablets (sublingual immunotherapy) administered over time to desensitize the immune system and reduce allergy symptoms.
Identifying and avoiding allergens such as pollen, pet dander, dust mites, mold, or certain foods through environmental modifications or lifestyle changes to minimize exposure.
Adequate rest and increased fluid intake help support the body's immune response during fever
Over-the-counter medications like acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen can help reduce fever and alleviate symptoms
Applying cool compresses or damp cloths to the forehead, neck, or armpits can help lower body temperature.
Taking a lukewarm bath or shower can help cool the body and provide temporary relief from fever.
If fever persists, is accompanied by severe symptoms, or occurs in vulnerable populations (e.g., infants, elderly), medical evaluation is advised.
Get plenty of rest and drink fluids like water, herbal tea, or clear broth to stay hydrated and support recovery.
Use over-the-counter cold medications for symptom relief, such as decongestants, antihistamines, or pain relievers.
Gargling with warm salt water can soothe a sore throat and help reduce inflammation.
Inhaling steam from a bowl of hot water or using a humidifier can ease nasal congestion and improve breathing.
Minimize exposure to smoke, pollution, allergens, and other irritants that can worsen cold symptoms.
Drink plenty of fluids, such as water, clear broths, electrolyte solutions, or oral rehydration solutions (ORS), to prevent dehydration.
Get adequate rest and consume easily digestible foods like bland soups, crackers, bananas, rice, and toast (BRAT diet).
Use ORS solutions available at pharmacies to replace lost electrolytes and fluids during bouts of diarrhea and vomiting
Avoid spicy, greasy, or heavy foods, as well as alcohol, caffeine, and tobacco, which can irritate the stomach and worsen symptoms
Over-the-counter medications like antiemetics (to reduce nausea/vomiting) or antidiarrheals (to control diarrhea) may be used as directed.
